Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) 291 Daehak-ro Yuseong-gu Daejeon 305-701 Republic of Korea Graphical abstract Cobalt-based catalysts having different base strengths were prepared by controlling the amount of yttrium oxide (Y2O3). These catalysts were used for the facile one-pot synthesis of polyetheramine (PEA) from polypropylene glycol (PPG) through reductive amination. It is noticed that high hydrogen partial pressures up to 40 bar inhibit the formation of cobalt nitride and lead to a high PEA yield although it has been known that dehydrogenation from alcohol to ketone is the rate-determining step. The Y2O3-inserted Co-Pd/Molecular sieve13X catalyst also showed high activity toward PEA even at low hydrogen partial pressure. Y2O3 played a crucial role in giving basicity to the catalyst, which not only prevents the formation of cobalt nitride but also promotes hydrogenation of imine to amine at a wide range of H2 pressure. Thus Y2O3 inserted Co-Pd/Molecular sieve 13X provides unique performance toward enhancing the PEA yield while suppressing the catalyst deactivation caused by the cobalt nitride formation. Keywords Polyetheramine Polypropylene glycol Reductive amination Yttrium oxide Cobalt-based catalysts 1 Introduction Polyetheramine (PEA) is an intermediate chemical for the curing agent of epoxy resin, polyurea coatings, wind turbine blade composites and adhesives. It has various molecular weights depending on the number of propylene oxide (PO) as repeating units in the backbone. The low molecular weight PEA is usually employed as an epoxy curing agent while the PEA with a long chain backbone is used for the polyurea coating. The market for PEA has gradually increased over the last decades to meet the growing demand [1]. However, the synthesis route for PEA has not been clearly disclosed yet and fundamental understanding on the reaction mechanism has been limited. PEA is normally synthesized from polypropylene glycol (PPG) with a terminal alcohol group via reductive amination. The reductive amination of polypropylene glycol consists of three steps as shown in Fig. 1 . First, the dehydrogenation of polypropylene glycol proceeds to yield the corresponding ketone intermediate. Then NH3 reacts with the ketone intermediate to form imine, releasing H2O during the second step reaction. Finally, PEA is produced by the hydrogenation of the imine intermediate through hydrogen released from the 1st step for the dehydrogenation of PPG [2]. Dehydrogenation has been known to be a rate-determining step among these reaction steps [3,4]. All of the steps are reversible reaction and occur in series [4,5]. According to prior works on the reductive amination from alcohol, transition metals of Cu, Ni, Co, etc. were mainly used as important active components for hydrogenation and dehydrogenation. For the PEA synthesis, Ni/Al2O3 or Mg-Ni catalyst was used for the polyethylene glycol (mw: 400) amination [6,7] but its amine yield was low (60.8% or 58.4%). Cu-Ni based catalysts were also employed for the amination of poly(oxytetramethylene) glycol (mw : 2000) in a batch reactor, and the amine yield was not that high (around 81.2%) although the catalysts were introduced in excess (16 wt% based on the poly oxytetra- methylene glycol) with the sufficient H2 (23.8 bar) pressure [8]. When methyl polyalkylene glycol (mw : 2000) was aminated under Co based catalysts, its amine yield was just 85% at 10 bar of H2 introduced though a lot of ammonia was introduced to increase reactivity and reaction was proceeded even for 12 h [9]. A Co-Cu-Ti catalyst was utilized in a batch reactor for the reductive amination of PPG-2000, its amine yield reached 97% at around 27 bar of H2 in 6 h [10]. In addition, the PEA synthesis was carried out under harsh conditions over 200 bar and 200 °C [9,11]. Other Co based catalysts were also used for the synthesis of monoisopropylamine (MIPA) [12] but the maximum yield of MIPA was about 79%. It was reported that Ni/LaAlSiO catalysts having a basic property were able to promote the amination of isopropyl alcohol [13] but they provided the isopropyl amine yield lower than 95%. A significant catalyst activity was required for the reaction to completely proceed because the product PEA having an average molecular weight of 2000 has an extremely low vapor pressure (1.24 × 10−3 bar at 235 °C) so it is difficult to separate the product from the main reactant (PPG-2000) mixture. Another problem in addition to the insufficient catalyst activity is the generation of cobalt nitride during the amination. It has been considered as an inactive species hindering the reductive amination [4,14]. Thus it will be a key task to suppress the formation of cobalt nitride during the reaction for improving the activity toward amine. The present study introduces the incorporation of a small amount of Y2O3 into Co-Pd/Molecular sieve 13X catalysts for inhibiting the cobalt nitride formation and elevating the yield of PEA prepared from PPG via reductive amination. It will be shown how the introduction of Y2O3 gives basic properties to the catalysts and inhibits the formation of cobalt nitride between cobalt and ammonia. Also it will be demonstrated that the addition of Y2O3 can promote imine hydrogenation toward amine even under low hydrogen partial pressures. To the best of our knowledge, Y2O3-inserted Co-Pd/Molecular sieve 13X catalysts have never been explored for the reductive amination of polypropylene glycol (PPG). This study will demonstrate the enhancement of reactivity for the reductive amination by the addition of Y2O3 to the Co based catalysts. CO2 temperature programmed desorption (TPD) will evaluate how the incorporation of Y2O3 can provide basic property for the catalyst. In order to check if cobalt nitride is formed, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) will mainly be used with the CO2 TPD measurements. Also Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) will be employed to confirm how many imine molecules are converted into amine molecules. Through these results, we will understand that the basic property of the catalyst plays a critical role in increasing amination performance as well as lowering reaction pressure. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Y2O3-inserted Co-Pd/Molecular sieve 13X (MS) catalysts were prepared by a precipitation method, varying with the amount of yttrium precursor (Y(NO3)3∙4H2O) introduced. 44.035 g of Co(NO3)2∙6H2O (ACROS), a fixed amount of Y(NO3)3∙4H2O (0 g, 0.263 g, 0.525 g, and 0.788 g (Sigma-Aldrich)) and 0.056 g of Pd(NO3)2∙2H2O (KOJIMA) were placed in each beaker, followed by introducing 200 ml, 10 ml and 10 ml, respectively of deionized water (DIW) to dissolve each precursor. These solutions were introduced to a glass-reactor equipped with an agitator. Then 12 g of non-activated (cationic, Na) molecular sieve 13X and 200 ml DIW were additionally mixed with the precursor solution. 195 g of 15 wt% Na2CO3 (Sigma-Aldrich) aqueous solution as a precipitation agent was dropped continually to the solution including each precursor and support for 1.5 h. After the aging process for additional 1.5 h, the filter cake was washed five times by deionized water (4.5 l). Then the catalysts were dried at 120 °C for 15 h and calcined at 600 °C for 4 h. For the H2-dependent reductive amination, 0.050 g of Pd(NO3)2∙2(H2O) was added to prepare Co-Y2O3-Pd/MS catalysts, where MS stands for molecular sieve 13X . These catalysts were denoted as Co-Y2O3(x)-Pd/MS, where x = 0, 0.5, 1.0, 1.5 as the amount of the yttrium precursor was increased to 0, 0.263 g, 0.525 g, and 0.788 g, respectively. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts Catalysts were characterized with an inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscope (ICP-mass) to obtain the elemental composition by Agilent ICP-MS 7700S. The surface area of the catalysts was determined by N2 adsorption–desorption at a liquid nitrogen temperature of 77.30 K by BEL Japan Belsorp Max. The crystalline phases of the catalysts were determined by high resolution powder X-ray diffraction (RIGAKU SmartLab). To check if cobalt nitride was formed, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed on Thermo VG Scientific K-alpha. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) was also carried out by using CO2 to measure the basicity of catalysts on BEL Japan Belcat. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometry was used to confirm the formation of imine on Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 with ZnSe windows through a transmission method. Each IR spectrum represents the average of 64 scans for the PEA products whose background spectrum was excluded. 2.3 Reductive amination test 2.3.1 Catalyst activation Y2O3 amount-dependent-reductive amination was carried out in a stainless batch reactor (200 ml). 70 g of PPG-2000 (SKC) and 3.5 g of the prepared catalyst powder were placed in the batch reactor. N2 purge was carried out 5 times and then H2 was introduced into the reactor until the reactor pressure reached 50 bar. The catalyst activation was performed at 220 °C, and 80 bar for 2 h. After the activation was completed, the reactor started to cool down to 180 °C and was vented down to 10 bar at that temperature. The reactor cooling was maintained until reaching room temperature and 5 bar of H2. Then H2 was discharged down to 1 bar. 2.3.2 Reductive amination NH3 was first introduced into the reactor at room temperature. The NH3 feeding amount was set to a mole ratio of NH3 to PPG equal to 40 (NH3/OH = 20). Then H2 was charged into the reactor up to 50 bar until its partial pressure reached 40 bar. One-pot reductive amination was carried out at 220 °C and 210 bar for 2.5 h. After finishing the reaction, the reactor started to cool down to 180 °C and NH3 and H2 were vented to 100 bar at that temperature. The reactor cooling was maintained until reaching room temperature and 30 bar of NH3 and H2. Then NH3 and H2 were discharged down to 1 bar and N2 purge was applied to remove remaining NH3. For the H2-dependent reductive amination, the reaction was carried out in a stainless batch reactor (1800 ml) for measuring amine yields through sampling over the time. 420 g of PPG-2000 (SKC) and 21.0 g of the prepared catalyst were placed in the batch reactor. The other conditions were the same as the conditions for experiments in the 200 ml batch reactor. 2.3.3 Post-treatment and analysis A mixture of PEA and catalyst was separated with a glass filtrator. Filtrated clear PEA was additionally purged with N2 for 1 h to completely remove remaining NH3. The total amine amount and primary amine amount were measured with a titration method [15]. For the total amine titration, around 3 g of product was placed in a beaker, followed by introducing 50 ml of isopropyl alcohol (IPA) to dissolve the product as a solvent. Then a couple of drops of bromophenol blue (BPB) solution (1 wt% BPB in IPA) were injected to the beaker as an indicator. The solution containing the product was titrated by using a hydrochloric acid solution (0.1 N HCl in IPA) while it was stirred. For the primary amine titration, the titration for the sum of secondary and tertiary amine should be first carried out. Around 1 g of product was placed in a beaker, followed by introducing 50 ml of chloroform to dissolve the product as a solvent. Then 3 ml of salicylaldehyde was introduced to the beaker. The solution was stirred and maintained for 30 min. A couple of drops of BPB solution were injected and the solution including the product was titrated by using the hydrochloric acid solution (0.1 N HCl in IPA). Titrated amines were for the sum of secondary and tertiary amine. The primary amine amount was calculated via the subtraction of the sum of secondary and tertiary amine amounts determined by titration from the total amine amount measured. The total amine yield was calculated by dividing the amine mole number measured via the titration by the PPG mole number introduced. The primary amine selectivity was calculated by dividing primary amine mole number measured through the titration by the total amine mole number measured via titration. FT-IR was used to determine if amine was actually formed [16]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity of Y2O3-inserted catalysts The elemental composition of as-prepared catalysts is given in Table 1 . With the increasing amount of the yttrium precursor, the yttrium contents in the catalysts increased. The formation of yttrium oxide was confirmed by XPS measurements in Fig. 2 and it showed that Y2O3 was included in the spent Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS catalyst (for more data, refer to Fig. S1). The XRD data in Fig. 3 A illustrated that cobalt oxide (CoO) was also formed in the Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS catalyst after the catalyst activation step. It was confirmed from the XRD data in Fig. 3B that the cobalt metal was formed in the spent Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS catalyst after the reaction at P(H2) = 40 bar, whereas Fig. 3C and D showed that cobalt oxide (CoO) and cobalt metal co-existed in the spent Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS catalyst with a lower reaction pressure of P(H2) = 10 bar (for the other catalysts, refer to Fig. S2) and only cobalt oxide (CoO) was present in the spent Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS catalyst after the reaction at P(H2) = 0 bar. Through the XRD data in Fig. 3, it was realized that the degree of catalyst reduction increased with H2 pressure and the CoO phase was fully reduced to the Co metal phase from the reductive amination at P(H2) = 40 bar. But the fully reduced Co metal was not found from the reductive amination at P(H2) = 10 and 0 bar. The metal particle size was similar to each other from the XRD data in Fig. 3B and in Table 1 (for more data, refer to Fig. S3). But it was difficult to check in the XRD data if Y2O3 existed because its amount was very small. So the existence of Y2O3 was confirmed by XPS in Fig. 2 and by ICP-mass in Table 1. The amount of Pd included was around 0.1 wt% as shown in Table 1 and too small for the Pd peak to be observed from XRD (Figs. 3 and S3). Also it was found that the Pd peak of catalyst in XPS was very weak (Fig. S4). The BET surface area of the catalyst was given in Table 1. It was shown that the surface area is comparable (around 200 m2/g) with each other despite of the addition of Y2O3. The reason why the surface area of all catalysts decreased to around 200 m2/g compared to molecular sieve 13X (about 540 m2/g) can be explained in the BET isotherm for Co-Y2O3-Pd/MS13X (Fig. S5). The micropore amount for the Co-Y2O3-Pd/MS13X catalyst was quite decreased compared to the bare MS13X (Fig. S5). It is realized that the micropore was blocked by the active metals while the mesopore was formed as the active materials were impregnated. The reductive amination for the production of PEA was carried out to test the activity of each catalyst prepared depending on the amount of Y2O3. Fig. 4 A showed that the total amine yield at P(H2) = 40 bar rose with the increasing amount of Y2O3 except for the Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS catalyst. The surface area of Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS in the BET data (Table 1) became slightly decreased compared to that of Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS. It was surmised that the cobalt metal site was blocked by excess Y2O3 in the Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS catalyst, which led to the decrease in the performance of dehydrogenation or hydrogenation on the surface of cobalt metal. The primary amine selectivity of Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS was extremely high, 99.7% in the total amine yield (99.3%) compared to that in a prior work where the primary amine (Monoisopropylamine : MIPA), selectivity was about 94% with a low total amine yield of 79% [12]. The primary amine selectivity for the amination of polyalkylene glycol (mw: 2000) was just about 80.8% in a total amine yield of 81.2% [8]. Thus, the catalysts proposed in this work were highly active and there was a significant effect of Y2O3 on improving the catalytic performance of the reductive amination. Also this catalyst showed good activity in the long term cycle test (at least 15 cycles) as shown in Fig. S6. Fig. 4B indicated the Y2O3–dependent reductive amination yield at P(H2) = 10 bar. It was noticed that the amine yield at P(H2) = 10 bar was lower than that at P(H2) = 40 bar in Fig. 4A, but the addition of Y2O3 into Co-Pd/MS brought a highly remarkable activity compared to the catalyst which didn’t contain Y2O3. Also it was seen that the total amine yield at P(H2) = 10 bar distinguishingly varied with the amount of Y2O3 compared to the results at P(H2) = 40 bar as shown in Fig. 4A. In other words, at a relatively low pressure of H2, the amount of Y2O3 in the catalyst has more dominant effect on the amine yield. At the low hydrogen pressure, it was reported that the catalytic activity decreased because ammonia was strongly interacted with the cobalt metal site of the catalyst that is active for dehydrogenation and hydrogenation [17]. Actually, another Co based catalyst that didn’t include Y2O3 approached to relatively low amine yield (85%) for the reductive amination of methyl polyalkyleneglycol (mw : 2000) having a backbone structure (polyether chain) similar to that in PPG at a hydrogen pressure of 10 bar after a very long reaction time (12 h) in spite of introducing a large excess of NH3 (NH3/OH = 38) [9]. But it was shown that a small insertion of Y2O3 into Co-Pd/MS catalyst (Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS13X) gave a similar amine yield at 10 bar of H2 for a short reaction time (2.5 h) with a lower NH3 amount (NH3/OH = 20). From results of Fig. 4A and Fig. 4B, it was surmised that both H2 and the addition of Y2O3 into Co-Pd/MS have a positive influence on improving the reactivity toward PEA while inhibiting the interaction of cobalt metal with ammonia that may lead to decreasing the catalytic activity. 3.2 H2-dependent reductive amination In order to confirm whether or not the reactivity of the reductive amination was influenced by the amount of H2, experiments for the Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS catalyst were carried out by varying the H2 pressure. Fig. 5 exhibited that the total amine yield decreased as the decreasing amount of H2. But this result conflicted with the fact that the rate determining step of dehydrogenation (1st step in Fig. 1) prefers a low hydrogen partial pressure. This counter-intuitive result can be due to the inhibition of cobalt nitride formation under the high partial pressure of H2. It was well known that ammonia strongly adsorbs on the cobalt metal, which can form cobalt nitride and result in the decreased activity of dehydrogenation and hydrogenation [14,17]. For P(H2) = 20 and 40 bar, at relatively high hydrogen pressures, it showed high total amine yields close to 99% in Fig. 5. But, surprisingly, in the case of P(H2) = 0 bar, a small amount of final product PEA was still observed even with no external H2 supply because there was some hydrogen available from dehydrogenation of PPG as shown in Fig. 1. However, overall, it was understood that the increase in H2 partial pressure above 10 bar has a positive influence on the reactivity toward PEA as shown in Fig. 5. At a low H2 pressure, it was reported that the catalytic activity was decreased because ammonia was strongly interacted with the cobalt metal site of the catalyst that is active for dehydrogenation and hydrogenation [17]. At a low H2 partial pressure, cobalt metal can be converted into cobalt nitride as shown in the following reaction [14]. (1) 3Co + NH3 ↔ Co3N + 1.5 H2 Thus, less hydrogen results in the lowered reactivity toward PEA due to the formation of cobalt nitride while it may favor the reactivity in view of dehydrogenation as a rate-determining step. 3.3 Effect of cobalt nitride formation on the amine yield Since both cobalt metal and cobalt oxide co-exist at a H2 partial pressure of 10 bar (Fig. 3C), the H2-dependent reductive amination was carried out with the spent catalyst having only cobalt metal (Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS that was subjected to the amination at P(H2) = 40 bar as shown in Fig. 3B). Thus, we excluded the effect of the generated cobalt oxide (CoO) on the amine yield and the CoO-free spent catalyst at P(H2) = 40 bar was secondly reused for the H2-dependent reductive amination at P(H2) = 40 bar, P(H2) = 10 bar and P(H2) = 0 bar, respectively. As shown in Fig. 6 , it was found that the catalytic activity was almost maintained even for the repeated use at P(H2) = 40 bar. The total amine yield 98.7% in the second use of the spent catalyst at P(H2) = 40 bar was almost the same as that in the first use (99.0%). Moreover, each used catalyst reduced to the cobalt metal showed a very comparable catalytic activity compared to that of the fresh catalysts that contained cobalt oxide resulting from the first amination at P(H2) = 0 bar and P(H2) = 10 bar. Thus, it could be surmised that the presence of cobalt oxide does not affect the amine yield but the formation of cobalt nitride does. In order to actually prove that the decrease in the catalytic activity was due to the formation of cobalt nitride, the variation of the formation of cobalt nitride with varying H2 pressure was captured through XPS. Fig. 7 showed XPS N 1s results for Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS catalysts after the second use in Fig. 6. It was shown that the peak at around 397 eV was remarkably formed in the catalyst undergoing the reductive amination at P(H2) = 0 bar. It is known that the peak at around 397 eV is assigned to cobalt nitride [18–20] and the peak at around 399.5 eV indicates nitrogen from PEA [21,22] or NHx or N2 chemisorbed on the catalyst [23]. However, the cobalt nitride peak almost disappeared in the catalyst subject to the reductive amination at P(H2) = 10 bar and it did not appear in the catalyst used for the reductive amination at P(H2) = 40 bar that has high amine yields in Fig. 6, indicating the formation of cobalt nitride as the decrease in H2 pressure led to a drop in the total amine yield. Thus, from the results in Figs. 6 and 7 combined with the XRD data in Fig. 3, it is understood that not the formation of cobalt oxide but the formation of cobalt nitride deteriorates the reactivity for PEA. So, it would be very important to come up with ways to suppress the formation of cobalt nitride for developing a highly active catalyst for the reductive amination. We are going to further discuss how Y2O3 can inhibit the cobalt nitride formation in the next section. 3.4 Role of basic Y2O3 3.4.1 Inhibited formation of cobalt nitride CO2-TPD was employed to determine the changes in the basicity of the catalyst with respect to the amount of Y2O3. As shown in Fig. 8 , the basicity was increased in this following order for the catalysts: Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS > Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS > Co-Y2O3(0)-Pd/MS > Co-Y2O3(0.5)-Pd/MS. It was conjectured that the higher amount of Y2O3 like in Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS, the more difficult to have a strong interaction with basic NH3, which was also supported by NH3-TPD (refer to Fig. S7) and the catalyst acidity increased in the following order: Co-Y2O3(0.5)-Pd/MS > Co-Y2O3(0)-Pd/MS > Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS > Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS. It was realized that the base catalyst which included a high amount of Y2O3, Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS, was difficult to have a strong interaction with the Lewis base component of NH3, which can reduce the access of NH3 to its surface. It should be noted that Co-Y2O3(0.5)-Pd/MS was slightly less basic than Co-Pd/MS because the latter has a larger intensity than the former in the CO2-TPD data as shown in Fig. 8. CO2-TPD of non-supported Co-Y2O3-Pd catalysts was also utilized to check how the basicity varys only with the Y2O3 amount when the basicity of the molecular sieve is absent (Fig. S8). The non-supported Co-Y2O3-Pd catalysts were washed by deionized water until the pH of filtrated water no longer dropped below 7.7 after the precipitation and aging step to completely remove the remaining basic Na2CO3 that was used as a precipitation agent. Thus the factors other than Y2O3 influencing the basicity of the catalysts were all excluded. The CO2-TPD data of the support-free catalysts showed the basicity increased with the increasing Y2O3 amount, which ensured that the addition of Y2O3 brings the increase in basicity of the catalyst (Fig. S8). Surprisingly, it was found that the catalyst basicity has a very close relation to activity for the PEA production. In Fig. 4B, as the catalyst basicity increased from the rise of Y2O3 contents, the higher total amine yield was obtained. For the Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS catalyst, its total amine yield was 25.3% higher than that of Co-Y2O3(0.5)-Pd/MS that has the lowest basic property, indicating that the catalyst basicity strongly influences the activity for PEA production. Fig. 9 showed the XPS results of the catalyst after the hydrogen-dependent amination. It was found that the catalyst surface after the reaction shown in Co 2p XPS data (Fig. 9A and B) was converted into the cobalt oxide form that is different from the XRD data showing the cobalt metal. Because XPS was not measured in a closed system, the surface of catalysts was actually exposed to the air and transformed to cobalt oxide while transferring the catalyst samples for the XPS analysis. For N 1s XPS data in Fig. 9C and D, two peaks existed. The peak at around 401.2 eV indicated N–H in PEA chemically adsorbed in the catalyst [22]. The other peak at 399.5 eV was assigned to C–N bonding from PEA chemically adsorbed in the catalyst [21,22,24,25] or nitrogen from NHx or N2 chemisorbed on the catalyst [23]. It is known that both cobalt metal and cobalt nitride peak are located at the very similar position around 777.5 eV [20]. So it was quite difficult to distinguish both of them exactly. According to XPS Co 2p data at P(H2) = 10 bar in Fig. 9A, the two catalysts of Co-Y2O3(0)-Pd/MS and Co-Y2O3(0.5)-Pd/MS had a newly appeared peak at around 777.5 eV which couldn’t find in the other catalysts. Considering our PEA reaction results at P(H2) = 10 bar, the peak at about 777.5 eV was cobalt nitride which plays a role in lowering the catalyst activity. The peak intensity at 777.5 eV increased with decrease in the amine yield as shown in the following order for the peak intensity: Co-Y2O3(0.5)-Pd/MS (Amine yield : 57.5%) > Co-Y2O3(0)-Pd/MS (60.7%) > Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS (74.9%) > Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS (82.8%). Also when comparing with Co 2p XPS results at P(H2) = 40 bar, we couldn’t observe the strong peak at 777.5 eV at P(H2) = 40 bar as much as shown at P(H2) = 10 bar. Since more hydrogen was introduced into the reactor at P(H2) = 40 bar, the possibility for the catalyst to exist as the cobalt metal state will be higher than that at P(H2) = 10 bar. So, this result strongly supports the peak at 777.5 eV (P(H2) = 10 bar) will be the peak for cobalt nitride. N 1 s XPS data in Fig. 9C more exactly showed that cobalt nitride was formed for Co-Y2O3(0.5)-Pd/MS at P(H2) = 10 bar because it is known that the peak at around 397 eV corresponds to cobalt nitride [18–20]. Co-Y2O3(0)-Pd/MS that showed the second lowest basicity had the small peak at around 397 eV and the cobalt nitride peak at 777.5 eV was slightly appeared at the Co 2p XPS data in Fig. 9A. Because the catalyst basicity for Co-Y2O3(0)-Pd/MS was slightly higher than Co-Y2O3(0.5)-Pd/MS catalyst, the alkaline NH3 will not favor its adsorption to the base catalyst surface and the amount of cobalt nitride formed by interaction with NH3 was presumably smaller (Fig. 9A). These results showed the catalyst including a proper amount of Y2O3 was able to help increase the basicity of the catalyst, which could hinder the access of NH3 to the surface of cobalt metal as indicated in Fig. 10 . Also it was found that the catalyst that contained a proper amount of Y2O3 efficiently inhibits the formation of cobalt nitride even under a low hydrogen partial pressure such as P(H2) = 10 bar compared to the catalyst that didn’t have Y2O3. Thus, the Y2O3-promoted catalyst could be a promising catalyst to reduce H2 pressure for the reductive amination. 3.4.2 Promotion of imine hydrogenation As already indicated in the CO2-TPD result of Fig. 8, the catalyst basicity generally increased as the Y2O3 amount increased and the Y2O3-inserted catalyst is quite capable of attracting the acidic site of molecules. In order to prove the effect of basic Y2O3 on the improvement of imine hydrogenation, IR was measured for PEA produced by each catalyst under a hydrogen pressure of P(H2) = 10 bar. As indicated in Fig. 11 , it was shown that the imine peak at around 1686 cm−1 disappeared as the increasing Y2O3 amount. Especially, the PEA product under the Co-Y2O3(0)-Pd/MS catalyst had relatively a high amount of imine due to inefficient hydrogenation of imine to amine under the low hydrogen partial pressure. Because the amine comes from the imine hydrogenation in the reductive amination, the limited hydrogen service could lead to the low conversion to amine. However, the imine content within the product under the Y2O3 promoted catalysts decreased with the increasing Y2O3 amount. In Fig. 11, the imine peak was almost disappeared especially in the product from the Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS catalyst. This result is ascribed to the efficient hydrogenation caused by the incorporation of Y2O3. In the PEA reaction mechanism, the imine is formed as an intermediate after ketone reacts with NH3. Imine has a double bond between carbon and nitrogen and because nitrogen’s electronegativity is higher than carbon, a partial positive charge will be found on the carbon. Such an electron-deficient carbon is in favor of access to the electron rich site. Thus, the electrophilic imine molecules would be adsorbed more easily on the surface of the Y2O3-inserted catalyst, which can help imine molecules quite frequently encounter hydrogen for hydrogenation. Contrary to NH3, molecular hydrogen should be dissociated into atomic hydrogen for hydrogenation in the PEA reaction mechanism. Because the dissociation of molecular hydrogen should be implemented on the surface of the catalyst, easier access of imine than ammonia to the surface of catalyst could increase the frequency of reaction between imine and atomic hydrogen. It is known that the carboxylic group having carbon with induced partially positive charge had an easy access to the basic site [26]. Through our IR result exhibiting decrease in the imine (1686 cm−1) content [27,28] as the increasing Y2O3 amount as shown in Fig. 11, it was realized that the imine adsorption on the catalyst was more likely determined by the Y2O3 amount. When introducing the same amount of hydrogen, increase in imine contents came with the low amine conversion by the Co-Y2O3(0)-Pd/MS catalyst, and decrease in imine contents was accompanied with the high amine conversion by the Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS catalyst. Although a limited hydrogen supply brought relatively a low conversion from imine to amine, addition of basic Y2O3 enabled for imine to convert to amine quite easily. Thus, Y2O3 can help promote hydrogenation even under the low hydrogen partial pressure and it is greatly anticipated that the Y2O3 inserted catalyst can reduce the reaction pressure. 4 Conclusions This work has examined the effect of increasing catalyst basicity in the Y2O3 incorporated Co-Pd catalyst on improving reactivity of the reductive amination for PEA. Although it was well known that dehydrogenation from alcohol to ketone is a rate-determining step and it prefers low hydrogen pressure, our result showed that less hydrogen didn’t ensure higher reactivity toward the amine. The low reactivity was owing to the formation of cobalt nitride and inefficient hydrogenation to amine. Increasing the catalyst basicity through addition of Y2O3 brought highly active catalyst performance. Our catalysts, especially Co-Y2O3(1.0)-Pd/MS and Co-Y2O3(1.5)-Pd/MS, were found to inhibit the formation of cobalt nitride and inhibit the access of NH3 to the surface of catalyst due to their basic property coming from the Y2O3 incorporation. The catalyst was quite capable of attracting electrophilic imine molecules, which led to promoting the imine hydrogenation from their contact with atomic hydrogen more frequently on the surface of the catalyst even under low hydrogen partial pressures. The Y2O3-inserted catalysts play a significant role not only in preventing the formation of cobalt nitride but also in promoting hydrogenation of imine even under low hydrogen partial pressures. Thus, the Y2O3-inserted catalysts could provide a high PEA yield with flexible hydrogen partial pressures. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt-based catalysts having different base strengths were prepared by controlling the amount of yttrium oxide (Y2O3). These catalysts were used for the facile one-pot synthesis of polyetheramine (PEA) from polypropylene glycol (PPG) through reductive amination. It is noticed that high hydrogen partial pressures up to 40 bar inhibit the formation of cobalt nitride and lead to a high PEA yield although it has been known that dehydrogenation from alcohol to ketone is the rate-determining step. The Y2O3-inserted Co-Pd/Molecular sieve13X catalyst also showed high activity toward PEA even at low hydrogen partial pressure. Y2O3 played a crucial role in giving basicity to the catalyst, which not only prevents the formation of cobalt nitride but also promotes hydrogenation of imine to amine at a wide range of H2 pressure. Thus Y2O3 inserted Co-Pd/Molecular sieve 13X provides unique performance toward enhancing the PEA yield while suppressing the catalyst deactivation caused by the cobalt nitride formation.
coredata.dc:title: Y2O3-Inserted Co-Pd/zeolite catalysts for reductive amination of polypropylene glycol
